title: ASL 64 — Timeline Planning & Resource Sharing
objectives: Practice sequencing due dates with ASL time-first ordering.
Negotiate blockers and resources with a partner using clear signing.
Apply SEL-7 focus on Responsible Decision-Making and Collaboration.

vocab.def: In ASL, time expressions (e.g., TOMORROW, NEXT-WEEK) usually come at the start of the sentence.
Something that prevents a task from moving forward.
A person, material, or tool needed to complete a task.

sections.heading: Warm-Up — Time Sequencing
sections.body: Sign TODAY, TOMORROW, NEXT-WEEK. Then add due items (ASSIGNMENT, VIDEO, QUIZ).

callouts.title: Time-First
callouts.body: Always lead with the time phrase before describing the task.

sections.heading: Blocker + Resource Drill
sections.body: Partner A signs a blocker (e.g., COMPUTER BROKE). Partner B responds with a resource (e.g., FRIEND HELP, LAB COMPUTER). Switch roles.

sections.heading: Mini-Dialogue
sections.body:
Practice a 2–3 exchange sequence:
1. TIME-FIRST + TASK
2. BLOCKER
3. RESOURCE
4. CONFIRMATION

sections.heading: Reflection
sections.body: Which needs practice — time-first due lines, blocker clarity, or resource ownership?

microCheck.q: In ASL, where do time phrases typically appear?

items.prompt: Which part of planning felt most clear? Which needs more practice?

reflectionPrompt: Upload your 25–35s planning clip. Caption M1–M3 dates, the blocker, the resource requested, and the solution.
summary: You sequenced due dates with time-first order, negotiated blockers, and practiced resource sharing.
